column4: which update option should i use? "normal releases" or "lts"?
do you want normal releases or just LTS releases?
well, i'm not quite sure, if i plan to update to 10.10 asap then i'll need normal releases i guess?
yes, normal
copy over ~otheraccount/.* ?

sorry I don't understand what you're saying, I have 1 account atm, I just want another name for it, but that's impossible, so I'll make a new one, but I'd like it to have all the programs I currently have, and if possible my documents too
ok, do this then... copy /home/otheraccount to /home/newaccount
how do I make a new account? ><
system -> administration -> users and groups
I made a new account, now what?
do what I said?
but the new account says it's a desktop user, but my current one is a custom one
you should give the new account admin rights
done, is that the root now?
no.  It has sudo privileges
ok, do this then... copy /home/otheraccount to /home/newaccount
do i need to close all the opened programs in order to get that command to work?
i can't find the new account
where are you looking?
no, look in /home
if i do ctrl-h i get folders of programs i have installed, do i need to copy those too?
yeah
after you copy them, you'll need to modify ownership
i can copy, but not paste
right, you'll have to do it as superuser.  You can do: gksudo nautilus
i got an error from chromium
what error?
SingletonSocket
why are you running chromium?  Are you running it as the old user?  The new user?  Did you modify the ownership rights for the files you copied already?
i'm running chromium to listen to music
I asked more than one question :/
i'm running it as the old user, didn't modify anything so far
don't know about chromium
if you want
it asks me: A file named ".bash_logout" already exists.  Do you want to replace it?
doesn't matter, they should be the same anyway
now i'll log out from my old and log in my new one?
no, update the ownership first
how do i do that?
sudo chown -R NAME_OF_NEW_USER_GOES_HERE: /home/NAME_OF_NEW_USER_GOES_HERE
yes, and all of the characters around it exactly
it didn't give me any output, that good?
yes, no output is always good.  Linux will only tell you when something goes wrong
sure
may I remove the old account now?
I'd keep it around for a couple of days just in case
it's not a big deal, but all the icons of my folders in the sidebar of nautilus are the same, can i change them back to their original ones?
oh-oh, I found a bug I think, my globalmenubar gives me the documents folder from my old acc instead of my new one
that's probably just because the setting had your old user explicitly.  You'll have to reset that when you come across it
where do i come across it? :S
when i log back in my new acc, it logs me in, but then says my keyring pass was wrong, and then i have to enter the old pass again
I've been able to solve all my issues I had with the new account except for one; when I'm logged in, it first prompts me to enter the old password again
with your keyring?
yeah!
there should be a program that allows you to manage your keyring in either the Accessories menu or the System menu
sorry but I can't find it ><
I'm not in gnome atm so can't tell you exactly where it is
are you on Gnome atm?
no
why?
remember the keyring problem?
oh, you haven't found the program yet?
yeah exactly
hold on, I'll log into gnome
Accessories -> Passwords and Encryption Keys
I looked there, can't find it ><
do you have anything listed there?
under the Passwords tab?
isn't there something like a "keyring" tab?
Passwords, My personal keys, Other keys
well is there anything in any of them?
under the tab Passwords, there's a folder Passwords, I expand that, and get 5 things
it's probably this
going to get some dinner
bon appetit
are you on Gnome?
I'm never on gnome, just ask though :)
oh.  Describe exactly when you get asked for it and ask the channel, someone may know
you can't right click on "Passwords: login" and select "change password"?
sweet!!!! that works
and update ownership of files, yeah
I remember you, you helped me last time :D
chown -R $USER: ~
don't do that in the wrong place, or it will mess up your system :)
may i pm u real qucik?
easier to stay in the channel, and that way others can help too
the syntax is: chown USERNAME:GROUP PATH.  Or if the username and the group is the same, you can use the shorthand: chown USERNAME: PATH.  And if you want it to be recursive, you use -R
you don't tell it the old username, you just tell it the new USERNAME you want the file to belong to
well, you need the path at the end
when I have copied everything over to the new username folder, I open a terminal and type in "chown -R /home/newusername"?
chown -R newusername: /home/newusername
does it require a sudo?
